@Zython86 That's what I mean by "the Planet does the pushback". Holy saves the planet from the two greatest threats: Meteor and humanity.
The blame rest far more in the genre's form than a particular series. You could level these complaints against Ultima. And do so stronger.
IV and V are the major exceptions to this, where the criticism might apply. Possibly XV, depending on the path it takes.
But as a whole, to position FF as a series about fascism sort of characterizes the ways in which fascism functions and manifests?
IV does this. Cecil and Rosa end up ruling over Baron in TAY and Cecil is "special" as a Lunarian.
A broader, grosser power narrative would not just deny old institutional powers but replace them with self serving ones.
And sure: X and LR play into the gotterdammerung angle. There's no denying that. But they impose no rules after God is dead.
The particular exception is X, with Yuna and Tidus completing what Braska, Jecht, and Auron could not.
The series has been going on for twenty years while, at least narratively, denying the power fantasy posited by the criticism.
So, while early titles (particularly V) might fall into the fascist power narrative, this starts to ease off a lot once you hit 1997.
(Everyone should play Lightning Returns. It is absolutely scathing in its religious implications.)
In fact, this thesis is so present in that series that in Lightning Returns, she literally kills god and then settles for a simple life.
XIII rests in a similar area. You may be fated to do something or divinely charged. The solution is to refuse the call.
XII focuses a lot on the ways in which people use power and posits that the good and dutiful thing is to relinquish and let go.
XII is explicitly about relinquishing seemingly divine granted power. That's Ashe's entire story arc and the core of the game.
Squall gets political power when he is chosen to command the Garden but he lacks the broader ambition to use it in any manifest form.
...that game is explicitly about how fucked up the people in jRPGs would actually be.
In VIII, Squall might be fated, thanks to time travel shenanigans, to be the one who kills the Sorceress but...
As in, yeah, the heroes stop the bad guy. But Meteor still falls and the Planet does the pushback. Potentially by killing humanity.
With VII, Cloud is a pretender who wields very little individual power. Beyond this, the original end implies the Planet saves itself.
....I feel that VII, VII, XII and even XIII don't play into that. Let's go over why that might be the case.
(Which, for the record, applies often to RPGs as a form. They're power politics are often very reductive and narrow minded.)
While I get the inherent idea: that RPGs position players as absolute authorities charged on mandate quests to "better" the world...
I gotta take a nap but I've been thinking re: some thoughts I saw about Final Fantasy as fascist narratives.
